questions.question: What is the primary purpose of Natural Language Processing (NLP)?

options.B: Programmatically understanding and quantifying information in natural language

questions.question: Which of the following are considered examples of unstructured data?

options.C: Written texts such as documents or transcripts

questions.question: NLP originally emerged to address which primary challenge, according to the lecture?

options.B: Automated translation after World War II

questions.question: Which are applications of NLP mentioned in the materials?
Natural language, as defined in the module, is primarily:
Which of the following are NOT natural languages?

sections.title: Section 3: Key Steps of the NLP Process

questions.question: Why is it important to understand the differences between natural languages and computer languages for NLP?

options.A: Because computer languages have fewer grammar rules
options.B: Because NLP tools are designed for languages meant to convey information between humans
options.C: Because both use the same vocabulary
options.D: Because natural languages are always written, while computer languages are spoken

questions.question: According to the lecture, what are the core steps in an NLP workflow?

options.D: Data Entry, Data Cleaning, Model Deployment

questions.question: Which of the following statements about pre-processing in NLP are correct?

options.A: Pre-processing quality affects the overall quality of NLP analysis
options.B: Pre-processing is only necessary for audio data
options.C: Pre-processing can be easy or cumbersome, depending on the data
options.D: Pre-processing is unnecessary for structured tabular data

questions.question: Measurement and extraction in NLP can best be described as:

options.A: Data in a strict table format
options.B: Data not ready for direct analysis, such as text, audio, or video

questions.question: According to the lecture, which of the following are key terms/concepts to remember in NLP?
Which of the following best distinguishes "latent features" as used in NLP applications?

options.A: Obvious characteristics of text such as word count
options.B: Hidden or underlying properties not explicitly visible in text
options.C: Features only found in audio data

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT mentioned as an application of NLP in the lecture?
Why did the need for NLP arise after WWII?

options.A: The volume of intercepted documents exceeded the capacity for manual translation
options.B: Real-time translation was required for diplomatic purposes
options.C: Computers were first becoming available for such tasks
options.D: Manual translation was too slow to keep up with intelligence demands

questions.question: According to the transcript, which of the following best describes a "black box" in NLP?

options.A: A pre-trained classifier or model whose internal workings are not necessarily understood
options.B: A graphical user interface for annotation

questions.question: Based on the lecture, why is preprocessing especially important in NLP?

options.A: Poor preprocessing may lead to inaccurate analysis
options.B: High-quality preprocessing can be time-consuming for complex data types
options.C: Preprocessing is only needed for simple text documents
options.D: Preprocessing can involve cleaning HTML tags and handling embedded media

questions.question: "Spoken word" is included as a type of unstructured data because:

options.A: It is always accompanied by video
options.B: It is a form of natural language that can be analyzed programmatically
options.C: It is always structured in tables
options.D: It is only used in corporate environments

questions.question: In what ways can NLP be used to process conference call data, according to the transcript?

options.A: Mapping transcript text to audio timing
options.C: Generating new voices from written script
options.D: Measuring when certain topics are discussed

questions.question: In summary, what does NLP refer to?

options.B: Techniques for programmatically processing natural language
